results:
Based on the search results, I found information about monuments, museums, and cultural commemorations related to Bolesław Prus and his novel "Lalka" (The Doll) in Poland:

## Monuments and Memorials

There is a Bolesław Prus Monument located on Twardowski Square in Warsaw, near the intersection of Krakowskie Przedmieście and Karowa Streets. The monument depicts Bolesław Prus as an elderly man in a pensive pose, holding a cane behind his back.(no content)Additionally, there is a bust of Bolesław Prus in Warsaw, placed in front of the Bolesław Prus 35th General Education High School at 7 and 9 Zwycięzców Street, in the Saska Kępa neighbourhood. The sculpture was made by Stanisław Sikora and unveiled on 19 May 1983. The monument consists of a dark brown stone bust depicting Bolesław Prus, placed on a red sandstone pedestal, and is around 3-metres-tall.

## Museums

The Bolesław Prus Museum in Nałęczów operates with opening hours daily except Mondays and days following public holidays, 10am-3pm. The museum, which opened in 1961, occupies two rooms in the Malachowski palace, which was built in the years 1751-1773.

## Cultural Events

There is evidence of cultural events such as "All Poland's reading" – "Lalka" (The Doll) by Bolesław Prus organized by cultural centres.

## Literary Significance

The Doll (Polish: Lalka) is the second of four acclaimed novels by the Polish writer Bolesław Prus and has been regarded by some, including Nobel laureate Czesław Miłosz, as the greatest Polish novel.(no content)Bolesław Prus wrote The Doll with such close attention to the physical detail of Warsaw that it was possible, in the Interbellum, to precisely locate the very buildings where, fictively, Wokulski had lived and his store had been located on Krakowskie Przedmieście. Prus thus did for Warsaw's sense of place in The Doll in 1889 what James Joyce was famously to do for his own capital city, Dublin, in the novel Ulysses a third of a century later.

The search results show that Bolesław Prus and his masterwork "Lalka" are commemorated through various monuments, museums, and cultural events across Poland, particularly in Warsaw and Nałęczów, reflecting the enduring cultural significance of this important Polish author and his literary contributions.
